result.note: In British English it is usual to spell this word blonde when writing about a woman or girl and blond when writing about a man or boy, although the spelling blonde is sometimes used for men and boys too. In American English the spelling blond is often preferred for either sex. Blonde may be used to describe a woman’s hair, but it is sometimes considered offensive to refer to a woman as ‘a blonde’ because hair colour should not define what a person is like.

idioms.text: if you can’t beat them, join them
idioms.sense: if you cannot defeat somebody or be as successful as they are, then it is more sensible to join them in what they are doing and perhaps get some advantage for yourself by doing so
far away from other people, houses, etc.
examples: They live miles off the beaten track.

idioms.text: a rod/stick to beat somebody with
idioms.sense: a fact, an argument, etc. that is used in order to blame or punish somebody
to be difficult to beat
examples: That score is going to take some beating.
For sheer luxury, this hotel takes some beating.

senses.text: large in size, degree, amount, etc.
examples: a big man/house/increase
This shirt isn't big enough.
It's the world's biggest computer company.
(informal) He had this great big grin on his face.
The lobster's claws are bigger than human hands.
The festival is getting bigger every year.
Her smile grew bigger.
They were earning big money.
The news came as a big blow.
a large amount of
a large number of
a large quantity of
a great deal of
in great detail
a person of great age
He was a big man—tall and broad-shouldered.
He was a short man with great big glasses.
This house is rather big for us. We need something smaller.
There's been a big increase in prices.
We were hoping the show would be a really big success.
The whole story is just a big fat lie.
my big brother
You're a big girl now.
It's a big decision to have to make.
You are making a big mistake.
Unemployment is a big problem in the region.
This legislation will make a big difference.
The big question is: why did they do it?
Housing is a big issue in London.
a potentially big drawback
She took the stage for her big moment.
It doesn't get bigger than the World Cup Final!
Tonight is the biggest match of his career.
(informal) Do you really think we can take on the big boys (= compete with the most powerful people)?
They're full of big ideas.
Orange is the big colour this year.
big in… The band's very big in Japan.
I'm a big fan of hers.
a big eater/drinker/spender
He gave me an extra five pounds for two hours' work. I thought ‘That's big of you’.

idioms.text: be/get too big for your boots (North American English also be/get too big for your britches)
idioms.sense: to be/become too proud of yourself; to behave as if you are more important than you really are
an important and powerful person, especially in an organization
used to say that you are not impressed by something
examples: So he earns more than me. Big deal!

idioms.sense: the most important person or thing

idioms.text: a big fish (in a small pond)
idioms.sense: an important person (in a small community)
a weak man, who is not brave or confident
the ability to keep moving ahead of your competitors, especially in politics
examples: In politics, momentum is known as the big mo.
He's picking up a lot of support and has the big mo.

idioms.sense: an important person
the situation as a whole
examples: Right now forget the details and take a look at the big picture.

idioms.sense: the use or threat of force or power
examples: The authorities used quiet persuasion instead of the big stick.

idioms.sense: the three, four, etc. most important countries, people, companies, etc.
examples: She works for one of the Big Six.

idioms.text: somebody’s eyes are bigger than their stomach
idioms.sense: used to say that somebody has been greedy by taking more food than they can eat
to show your approval of somebody by clapping your hands; to be applauded in this way
examples: Ladies and gentlemen, let’s give a big hand to our special guests tonight.

idioms.sense: to have more important or more interesting things to do
to be bad at keeping secretsto talk too much, especially about your own abilities and achievements
on a large/small scale
examples: The new delivery service has taken off in a big way.
Many people are investing in a small way in the stock market.
He then started spending money in a big way.

idioms.sense: to make something seem more important than it really is
used when you realize that you have said something that you should not have said
used to say that something is not important or not a problem
examples: If I don't win it's no big deal.

idioms.sense: so important to the economy of a country that when it finds itself in financial trouble, the government or central bank must act to save it
examples: Shouldering the huge costs of rescuing banks that are too big to fail has been left to taxpayers.

result.note: In sense 14 blowed  /bləʊd/  /bləʊd/is used for the past participle.

senses.text: to send out air from the mouth
examples: + adv./prep. You're not blowing hard enough!
The policeman asked me to blow into the breathalyser.
blow something + adv./prep. He drew on his cigarette and blew out a stream of smoke.
The birds were singing and a warm wind was blowing.
+ adv./prep. A cold wind blew from the east.
It was blowing hard.
It was blowing a gale (= there was a strong wind).
The wind blew the door shut.
Both candidates wore blue jeans.
They chose an intense blue for the walls.
+ adv./prep. My hat blew off.
+ adj. The door blew open.
blow somebody/something + adv./prep. I was almost blown over by the wind.
She blew the dust off the book.
The ship was blown onto the rocks.
The bomb blast blew two passers-by across the street.
blow something + adj. The wind blew the door shut.
the sound of trumpets blowing
blow something The referee blew his whistle.
She grabbed a tissue and loudly blew her nose.
to blow smoke rings
to blow bubbles (= for example, by blowing onto a thin layer of water mixed with soap)
to blow glass (= to send a current of air into melted glass to shape it)
The car spun out of control when a tyre blew.
The truck blew a tyre and lurched off the road.
The safe had been blown by the thieves.
One mistake could blow your cover (= make your real name, job, intentions, etc. known).
We’re going to blow his operation wide open.
He inherited over a million dollars and blew it all on drink and gambling.
She blew her chances by arriving late for the interview.
You had your chance and you blew it.
Blow it! We've missed the bus.
Well, blow me down! I never thought I'd see you again.
I'm blowed if I'm going to (= I certainly will not) let him treat you like that.
Let's take a taxi and blow (= never mind) the expense.
Let's blow this joint.
I like my old phone, but this new model blows it out of the water.

idioms.sense: to kill yourself/somebody by shooting yourself/them in the head
examples: He put a gun to his head and threatened to blow his brains out.
While cleaning his shotgun he had accidentally blown his own brains out.

idioms.sense: to vomit
to help somebody have a fresh, lively state of mind again
examples: A brisk walk should blow the cobwebs away.

idioms.sense: to get very angry
to tell something secret, especially by mistake
to change your opinion about something often
to produce a very strong feeling of pleasure or shock
examples: Wait till you hear this. It'll blow your mind.
a collection of photographs that will blow your mind

idioms.sense: to get rid of your energy, anger or strong emotions by doing something active or noisy
examples: I went for a long walk to let off steam.
I like blowing off steam and I like saying things that shock people.

idioms.text: blow somebody/something out of the water (informal)
idioms.sense: to destroy somebody/something completelyto show that somebody/something is not good by being very much better than it/them
examples: I like my old phone, but this new model blows it out of the water.

idioms.text: blow your own trumpet (especially British English) (North American English usually blow/toot your own horn)
idioms.sense: to praise your own abilities and achievements
to try to trick somebody or lie to somebody, particularly by saying something is better than it really is
to surprise or impress somebody very much

idioms.text: blow that for a lark (also taboo sod that for a lark)
idioms.sense: used by somebody who does not want to do something because it involves too much effort
examples: Sod that for a lark! I'm not doing any more tonight.

idioms.sense: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely
examples: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

idioms.sense: to completely destroy somebody/something with an explosion
examples: The truck was blown to kingdom come.

idioms.text: blow your top (North American English also blow your stack)
idioms.sense: to get very angry
if a plan, etc. blows up in your face, it goes badly wrong in a way that causes you damage or makes you feel embarrassed
to tell somebody in authority about something wrong or illegal that somebody is doing

idioms.text: it’s an ill wind (that blows nobody any good)
idioms.sense: no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody

idioms.text: lift the lid on something | take/blow the lid off something
idioms.sense: to tell people unpleasant facts about something
examples: Her article lifts the lid on bullying in the workplace.

idioms.text: puff and blow (also puff and pant informal)
idioms.sense: to breathe quickly and loudly through your mouth after physical effort
examples: Eventually, puffing and blowing, he arrived at the gate.

idioms.text: see which way the wind is blowing
idioms.sense: to get an idea of what is likely to happen before deciding what to do

senses.text: the part of the human body that is on the opposite side to the chest, between the neck and the tops of the legs; the part of an animal’s body that corresponds to this
examples: on your back He was lying on his back on the sofa.
Do you sleep on your back or your front?
with your back to somebody/something She was standing with her back to the camera so you can't see her face.
behind your back They had their hands tied behind their backs.
at your back They set off with the wind at their backs (= behind them).
your lower/upper back
in your/the back I have a nagging pain in my lower back.
Most of the victims were shot in the back.
a bad (= painful) back
I pulled (= injured the muscles in) my back playing squash.
She was laid up with severe back pain.
A small boy rode on the elephant's back.
He stood with his back to the door.
a back massage
He was carrying a small child on his back.
They blindfolded him and tied his hands behind his back.
He was standing with his back to the fire.
He smiled and gave me a hearty slap on the back.
He yawned and stretched his back as he got out of bed.
The cat arched its back and hissed at the dog.
He hunches his back when he walks.
His back stiffened as he saw the photographers waiting.
He leaned his back against the bar.
He's in bed with a bad back.
I was flat on my back for six weeks when I broke my leg.
She felt a sharp pain in the small of her back.
The sun beat down on their bare backs.
Would you give me a back rub?
I need a seat with good back support.
She broke her back in a riding accident.
He spent six months recovering from a broken back.
He put his back out (= dislocated something in his back) lifting the crates.
She was hit on the back of the head.
He kicked the ball straight into the back of the net.
The man was refusing to go to the back of the queue.
at the back The house has three bedrooms at the front and two at the back.
We could only get seats at the back (= of a room).
in the back (British English) There's room for three people in the back (= of a car, etc.).
in back (North American English) There's room for three people in back.
around the back Come around the back (= to the area behind the house) and I'll show you the garden.
What’s that at the back of the fridge?
Smoking is only allowed at the rear of the aircraft.
Our room was at the back of the hotel
There’s a lovely wood just behind our hotel
He was shot in the back of the knee.
I found some old photos at the back of the drawer.
They were sitting in the back of the truck.
My money's all fallen down the back of the cushion.
The cup had been pushed to the back of the cupboard.
Two passengers sat in the back of the car.
on the back Take a card and write your name on the back.
on the back of something He scribbled some figures on the back of an envelope.
at the back (of something) The television guide is at the back of the paper.
in the back (of something) The answer key is in the back of the book.
towards the back (of something) The article I mentioned is in that magazine—towards the back I think.
The arts page is usually towards the back of the newspaper.
a high-backed sofa
The children sat back to back so they couldn't see each others' drawings.
The team had to play three games back to back.
When on stage, try not to turn your back on the audience.
She turned her back on them when they needed her.
Some newspapers have turned their backs on discussion and argument.
She decided to turn her back on Paris and return home.

idioms.text: at/in the back of your mind
idioms.sense: if a thought, etc. is at the back of your mind, you are aware of it but it is not what you are mainly thinking about
examples: At the back of my mind was a small, warning voice, telling me it was wrong.
The problem was always at the back of my mind.

idioms.sense: when somebody's back is turned they are not present and not able to see what is happening
examples: Officers are ready to issue a parking ticket as soon as a driver's back is turned.

idioms.sense: a place that is a long way from other houses, towns, etc.
examples: We stayed in some farmhouse in the back of beyond.

idioms.sense: used to talk about planning or calculating something in a way that is not detailed, exact or complete
examples: We added up our savings on the back of an envelope.
back-of-the-envelope calculations

idioms.sense: if two people stand or sit back to back, they stand or sit with their backs facing or touching each otherif two or more things happen back to back, they happen one after the other
examples: The children sat back to back so they couldn't see each others' drawings.
The team had to play three games back to back.

idioms.text: back to front (British English) (North American English backwards)
idioms.sense: if you put on a piece of clothing back to front, you make a mistake and put the back where the front should be
examples: I think you've got that sweater on back to front.

idioms.text: be glad, etc. to see the back of somebody/something
idioms.sense: to be happy that you will not have to deal with or see somebody/something again because you do not like them or it
examples: Was I pleased to see the back of her!
I can’t wait to see the back of that old car.

idioms.sense: without somebody’s knowledge or permission
examples: Have you been talking about me behind my back?
They went ahead and sold it behind my back.
People say bad things about him behind his back, but never to his face.

idioms.sense: to keep asking or telling somebody to do something that they do not want to do, in a way that they find annoying
examples: He’s still on my back about that money I borrowed.

idioms.sense: to finish the largest or most important part of a task
examples: I want to break the back of this translation before the weekend.

idioms.text: cover your back (informal) (North American English also cover your ass taboo, slang)
idioms.sense: to realize that you may be blamed or criticized for something later and take action to avoid this
examples: Get everything in writing in order to cover your back.

idioms.sense: to annoy somebody
examples: That sort of attitude really gets my back up!

idioms.sense: to stop annoying somebody, for example by criticizing them, or asking them to do something
examples: Just get off my back, will you!

idioms.sense: to protect and support somebody
examples: Don't worry, I've got your back.
I’m loyal and I’ve got your back.

idioms.text: have your back to the wall
idioms.sense: to be in a difficult situation in which you are forced to do something but are unable to make the choices that you would like
examples: We had our backs to the wall with no choice but to sell.

idioms.text: have eyes in the back of your head
idioms.sense: to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see
examples: You can’t get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

idioms.text: know somebody/something inside out | know somebody/something like the back of your hand
idioms.sense: to be very familiar with somebody/something
examples: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

idioms.text: the last/final straw | the straw that breaks the camel’s back
idioms.sense: the last in a series of bad events, etc. that makes it impossible for you to accept a situation any longer

idioms.text: make a rod for your own back
idioms.sense: to do something that will cause problems for you in the future
immediately after something
examples: They come into this game off the back of a 1–0 defeat to Chelsea.

idioms.sense: as a result of an achievement or a success
examples: The profits growth came on the back of a 26 per cent rise in sales.

idioms.text: off the back of a lorry
idioms.sense: goods that fell off the back of a lorry were probably stolen. People say or accept that they came ‘off the back of a lorry’ to avoid saying or asking where they really came from.
in bed because you are ill
examples: She's been flat on her back for over a week now.
(figurative) The UK market was flat on its back (= business was very bad).

idioms.text: a pat on the back (for something/for doing something)
idioms.sense: praise or approval for something that you have done well
examples: He deserves a pat on the back for all his hard work.
Give yourself a pat on the back!

idioms.sense: to praise somebody or yourself for doing something well

idioms.text: push something to the back of your mind
idioms.sense: to try to forget about something unpleasant
examples: I tried to push the thought to the back of my mind.

idioms.sense: to use a lot of effort and energy on a particular task
anything that somebody has, including the things they really need themselves, that somebody else takes from them or they are willing to give
examples: He was the type of person who would give you the shirt off his back.

idioms.sense: an act that harms somebody, done by a person they thought was a friend
examples: Her refusal to support his campaign was a real stab in the back.

idioms.sense: to do or say something that harms somebody who trusts you
to turn so that you are facing in the opposite direction
to move so that you are standing or sitting with your back facing somebody/somethingto reject somebody/something that you have previously been connected with
examples: When on stage, try not to turn your back on the audience.
She turned her back on them when they needed her.
Some newspapers have turned their backs on discussion and argument.
She decided to turn her back on Paris and return home.

idioms.sense: to protect yourself against danger
examples: She'd better watch her back if she wants to hold onto the top job.

idioms.sense: used to say that something, especially criticism, has no effect on somebody/something
examples: I can't tell my son what to do; it's water off a duck's back with him.

idioms.text: you scratch my back and I’ll scratch yours
idioms.sense: used to say that if somebody helps you, you will help them, even if this is unfair to others

senses.text: used when you are naming people or things, describing them or giving more information about them
examples: + noun Today is Monday.
‘Who is that?’ ‘It's my brother.’
She's a great beauty.
Susan is a doctor.
He wants to be (= become) a pilot when he grows up.
+ adj. It's beautiful!
Life is unfair.
He is ten years old.
‘How are you?’ ‘I'm very well, thanks.’
Be quick!
be (that)… The fact is (that) we don’t have enough money.
be doing something The problem is getting it all done in the time available.
be to do something The problem is to get it all done in the time available.
+ adj. It was really hot in the sauna.
It's strange how she never comes to see us any more.
He thinks it's clever to make fun of people.
+ noun It would be a shame if you lost it.
It's going to be a great match.
Is there a God?
Once upon a time there was a princess…
I tried phoning but there was no answer.
There's a bank down the road.
Was there a pool at the hotel?
The town is three miles away.
If you're looking for your file, it's on the table.
Mary's upstairs.
She's from Italy.
The party is on Friday evening.
The meetings are always in the main conference room.
She has been in her room for hours.
They're here till Christmas.
I'll be at the party.
He'll be here soon (= will arrive soon).
+ noun It's two thirty.
+ adj. It was late at night when we finally arrived.
‘How much is that dress?’ ‘Eighty dollars.’
Three and three is six.
How much is a thousand pounds in euros?
Let x be the sum of a and b.
London is not England (= do not think that all of England is like London).
I've never been to Spain.
He had been abroad many times.
(British English) Has the postman been yet?
Is your jacket real leather?
be mine, yours, etc. The money's not yours, it's John's.
be for me, you, etc. This package is for you.
Money isn't everything (= it is not the only important thing).
A thousand dollars is nothing to somebody as rich as he is.

idioms.sense: as somebody/something used to be called
examples: Jill Davis that was (= before her marriage)
the Soviet Union, as was

idioms.sense: the most important part; all that matters
examples: Her career is the be-all and end-all of her existence.

idioms.text: (he, she, etc. has) been and done something
idioms.sense: used to show that you are surprised and annoyed by something that somebody has done
examples: Someone's been and parked in front of the entrance!

idioms.sense: used to say that somebody/something stopped somebody/something from happening
examples: If it weren't for you, I wouldn't be alive today.

idioms.sense: used to show that you accept that something negative cannot be changed
examples: I never imagined that our company share prices would fall so low, but it is what it is.

idioms.sense: to leave somebody/something alone without bothering them/it
examples: Leave her be, she obviously doesn't want to talk about it.
Let the poor dog be (= don't annoy it).

idioms.sense: future
examples: his bride-to-be
mothers-to-be (= pregnant women)
